content: Act as a helpful AI assistant
In Julia, Given a DataFrame df_cars with column `model`, write a function `count_model_rows` that groups data by model and calculate how many rows there are for each.

Sure! Here is an example of the code you would need to achieve this using the DataFrames library in Julia:

```julia
using DataFrames, CategoricalArrays  # assuming you have these packages installed

function count_model_rows(df::DataFrame)
    grouped = groupby(df, :model)
    counts = combine(grouped, size)[:x1]
end
```
This function first groups the DataFrame `df` by its column "model" using the `groupby` function. Then it uses the `combine` function to calculate the size of each group (i.e., how many rows there are for each model). Finally, it extracts and returns just the counts (:x1 in this case as DataFrames.jl will generate a temporary column named :x1)

You can then call your function with your dataframe:
```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(model=["A", "B", "A", "B", "C"])
println(count_model_rows(df_cars)) # prints [2, 2, 1]
```
